While a staunch opponent of the death penalty, the Justice is also known to be sympathetic to law enforcement on due-process issues—sometimes to the “right” of originalist Justices Antonin Scalia and Neil Gorsuch on searches and seizures.

This did not abate the fury of hardened progressives like Brian Fallon, Sen. Chuck Schumer’s former communications chief, whose court-packing group Demand Justice paid for a truck with a “Breyer, Retire” banner to drive around Washington.

Yet on the cases that most divide the Court and the country—those touching on race, sex, religious liberty and executive power—Justice Breyer has been a reliable vote for the politically progressive interpretation of the Constitution.

Justice Breyer sent Mr. Fallon’s followers into further bouts of apoplexy when he declined to retire in 2021, but the Justice is well aware that a GOP Senate in 2023 would make the confirmation of his successor more fraught.

The President would be wise to pick a liberal in the mold of Justices Breyer or Elena Kagan, rather than Sonia Sotomayor, who seems more interested in fiery dissents than persuading colleagues and shaping the law.
The two most-discussed candidates who meet Mr. Biden’s demographic litmus test are Leondra Kruger of the California Supreme Court and Ketanji Jackson, whom Mr. Biden recently elevated to the D.C.
In an April speech at Harvard Law School, “The Authority of the Court and the Peril of Politics,” Justice Breyer argued against court-packing, an idea that progressives in Congress have embraced.

The news leak that Justice Stephen Breyer plans to retire at the end of the current Supreme Court term won’t change the balance of power on the High Court.
He is the least hostile to business, bringing a law-and-economics view of antitrust in opinions on the First Circuit Court of Appeals and later to the High Court.
Mr. Biden’s campaign promise that he’d appoint a black woman to the Supreme Court is unfortunate because it elevates skin color over qualifications.
Like many liberals of his generation, he is an institutionalist who believes in the promise of the Constitution and incremental social improvement.
Appointed by Bill Clinton in 1994, the 83-year-old Justice Breyer is the second-longest serving member of the Court after Justice Clarence Thomas.

He warned that an independent judiciary plays a crucial role in peaceful self-government that could easily be undermined by political tampering.
The Justice’s institutional bent showed its value over the past year as he defended the Court against partisan attacks from the left.
But it does mean the loss of a pragmatic liberal, with no guarantee that his successor will have the same restraint or principles.
Who is Joe Biden likely to nominate to replace him, and how might this change affect the dynamic on the nation's highest court?
Justice Breyer’s openness to opposing views will be felt in deliberations, not least by Chief Justice John Roberts.
